{"step_by_step_thinking": "Peripheral eosinophilia is a condition characterized by an increase in the number of eosinophils in the peripheral blood. It can be caused by a variety of conditions, including allergies, infections, and certain diseases. Drug-induced interstitial nephritis can cause peripheral eosinophilia, as the body's immune response to the drug can lead to an increase in eosinophils. Polyangitis nodosa, a type of vasculitis, can also cause peripheral eosinophilia, as the inflammation of the blood vessels can lead to an increase in eosinophils. However, atheroembolic renal failure, which is caused by the blockage of small arteries in the kidneys by cholesterol emboli, is not typically associated with peripheral eosinophilia.", "answer_choice": "C. Atheroembolic renal failure"}
